user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 options)
{
    int                              return_code;
    pthread_mutexattr_t              mutex_attr;
    OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token);

    /*
    ** initialize the attribute with default values
    */
    return_code = pthread_mutexattr_init(&mutex_attr);
    if (return_code != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: Mutex could not be created. pthread_mutexattr_init failed ID = %lu: %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(return_code));
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /*
    ** Allow the mutex to use priority inheritance
    */
    return_code = pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_PRIO_INHERIT);
    if (return_code != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: Mutex could not be created. pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol failed ID = %lu: %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(return_code));
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /*
    **  Set the mutex type to RECURSIVE so a thread can do nested locks
    */
    return_code = pthread_mutexattr_settype(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_MUTEX_RECURSIVE);
    if (return_code != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: Mutex could not be created. pthread_mutexattr_settype failed ID = %lu: %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(return_code));
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    /*
    ** create the mutex
    ** upon successful initialization, the state of the mutex becomes initialized and unlocked
    */
    return_code = pthread_mutex_init(&impl->id, &mutex_attr);
    if (return_code != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: Mutex could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n", OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)),
                 strerror(return_code));
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemCreate_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t id;
} OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t OS_impl_mutex_table[OS_MAX_MUTEXES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in the provided function appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Reasoning for not selecting any fragments for further investigation:

- The function parameter token is declared as const OS_object_token_t *token, satisfying the rule that the pointer points to a const-qualified type when possible.
- The local pointer impl is used to obtain a mutable record from OS_impl_mutex_table and is later used to initialize impl->id via pthread_mutex_init. Since the pointed-to data is modified (mutex initialization changes the pthread_mutex_t), impl must point to a non-const type; therefore no const qualification is appropriate.
- The local variable mutex_attr is passed to pthread_mutexattr_init, pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol, and pthread_mutexattr_settype, all of which modify the attribute object. Thus mutex_attr cannot be const and the pointer usages are appropriate.
- pthread_mutex_init takes a const pthread_mutexattr_t * for its second parameter; passing &mutex_attr (a non-const object) is allowed and necessary because the same object is modified earlier. Making mutex_attr const would prevent those earlier modifications, so it is not possible nor desirable here.
- The macro usage OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token) expands to a subscript using OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok)). OS_ObjectIndexFromToken is declared to take a const OS_object_token_t *, so the const qualification is preserved for the index computation; there is no loss of const correctness requiring investigation.
- OS_ObjectIdFromToken is declared to take a const OS_object_token_t *, and it is called with token (const), so that use is correct.
- strerror returns a char * (implementation-defined) and is used only for diagnostic messages; this is a POSIX API characteristic and not something to change here to satisfy Rule 8.13.
- The global array OS_impl_mutex_table contains mutable mutex records (their pthread_mutex_t elements are initialized/modified at runtime), so it must be non-const.

Given the above, there are no pointer usages in the provided code that could sensibly be made to point to const-qualified types without breaking required behavior; therefore no suspicious fragments are reported.
